text.content: CONAN DOYLE, - The WHITE COMPANY has not yet turned up; but when it does - which I suppose will be next mail - you shall hear news of me.
I have a great talent for compliment, accompanied by a hateful, even a diabolic frankness.
Delighted to hear I have a chance of seeing you and Mrs. Doyle; Mrs. Stevenson bids me say (what is too true) that our rations are often spare.
As to ways and means, here is what you will have to do.

Leave San Francisco by the down mail, get off at Samoa, and twelve days or a fortnight later, you can continue your journey to Auckland per Upolu, which will give you a look at Tonga and possibly Fiji by the way.
Make this a FIRST PART OF YOUR PLANS.
A fortnight, even of Vailima diet, could kill nobody.
We are in the midst of war here; rather a nasty business, with the head-taking; and there seem signs of other trouble.
But I believe you need make no change in your design to visit us.
All should be well over; and if it were not, why!
you need not leave the steamer.

- Yours very truly,
ROBERT LOUIS STEVENSON.
